channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China Asks for Help Identifying and Returning Fugitive Officials
item.description: In the absence of extradition treaties with the most popular destinations for Chinese fugitives — Australia, Canada and the United States — the countries should “reform their laws” and ease extradition,” a Foreign Ministry official said.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Yu Zhendong, right, accused of embezzling $485 million from a state-owned bank, was arrested by the Chinese police in Beijing in 2004 after he was returned by the United States authorities on the condition that he would not be executed.

item.title: Gunmen in Pakistan Kill 4 Members of Anti-Polio Campaign
item.description: There was no immediate claim of responsibility for the attack, but Taliban militants have repeatedly targeted health workers in the area.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Op-Ed Contributors: Subcontracting Repression in the West Bank and Gaza
item.description: Palestinian security forces were supposed to help build a state. Instead, they’ve become a tool of the occupation.
item.dc:creator: By SABRIEN AMROV and ALAA TARTIR

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Bean Sprouts Tainted With Banned Additive Are Again Found in China
item.description: Sprouts produced at a site on the southern outskirts of Beijing were treated with high levels of 6-benzyladenine, a plant hormone, to speed up the growth cycle and make them more attractive to buyers, The Beijing News reported.
item.dc:creator: By JESS MACY YU
item.media:credit: Stew Milne for The New York Times
item.media:description: The additive enhanced the appearance and shortened the growing cycle of the bean sprouts, driving up profits.

item.title: Zimbabwe’s Ruling Party Bars Vice President From a Top Panel
item.description: Joice Mujuru, once seen as President Robert G. Mugabe’s heir apparent, was reported to have been disqualified because she had plotted to have him assassinated.
item.dc:creator: ALAN COWELL

item.title: Hong Kong Police Remove Protesters’ Camp After a Night of Chaotic Clashes
item.description: More than 100 demonstrators were arrested as the authorities dismantled barricades protecting a site where pro-democracy protesters had camped since late September.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY and ALAN WONG
item.media:description: The police used pepper spray Tuesday where pro-democracy demonstrators have camped since late September.

item.title: World Briefing: Egypt: Apartment Building Collapses
item.description: An apartment building in Cairo collapsed Tuesday, killing at least 19 people as rescuers and neighbors frantically dug through rubble with their hands to find survivors, the authorities said.

item.title: North Korean Leader Assails American ‘Aggressors’
item.description: The government staged a huge rally Tuesday against an American-backed effort to refer the North’s leaders to an international court for rights abuses.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: World Briefing: China: Coal Miners Die in Fire
item.description: A fire that followed underground tremors tore through a coal mine in northeastern China early Wednesday, killing 24 miners, the Chinese state news media reported.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Listening Post: For Former Embassy Hostages, a Special Interest in Iran Talks
item.description: For the 39 Americans still alive who were held captive in Tehran for 444 days from 1979 to 1981, there has been no financial compensation from Iran and financial deals to extend the nuclear talks add to their anguish.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER
item.media:credit: Travis Dove for The New York Times
item.media:description: David M. Roeder, a retired Air Force colonel, at his daughter’s home in North Carolina, is one of the 52 Americans held hostage in Tehran for 444 days from 1979 to 1981.

item.title: U.N. Urges Protection of Privacy in Digital Era
item.description: The United Nations adopted a resolution that signaled growing international attention on the issue of digital privacy, which it described as a human right.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: U.N. Extends Help for South Sudan
item.description: The United Nations Security Council voted unanimously on Tuesday to extend its peacekeeping mission in South Sudan, where a nearly year-old civil conflict has killed thousands of civilians.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: U.S.-Led Raid Rescues Eight Held in Yemen
item.description: The freed captives were six Yemeni citizens, a Saudi and an Ethiopian, who were unharmed, Yemeni officials said in a statement.
item.dc:creator: By ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: Runoff Will Decide President of Tunisia
item.description: As no presidential candidate secured a majority, the two front-runners in the race will face each other, the election board announced on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: By CARLOTTA GALL

item.title: Jam Journal: A Call to Save a 12th-Century Minaret, Heard Far and Wide
item.description: The Minaret of Jam, in a mountainous, remote region of Afghanistan, is leaning more and more, and officials fear it could fall.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND
item.media:description: The Minaret of Jam stands precariously in a gorge in west-central Afghanistan. Its remote location is all but impossible to visit.

item.title: World Briefing: Syria: Scores Are Killed in Airstrikes by Government on Islamic State’s Base
item.description: Syrian government warplanes killed at least 60 people Tuesday in airstrikes on Raqqa in northeastern Syria, the de facto capital of the Islamic State, activists said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Italy: Lawmakers Approve Jobs Bill
item.description: Italy’s lower house of Parliament voted Tuesday to pass Prime Minister Matteo Renzi’s Jobs Act.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Colombia: Rebels Free Two Soldiers
item.description: The country’s main rebel group on Tuesday released two low-ranking soldiers captured after a recent clash with government troops, but it remained unclear when it would free a general and two others it seized separately.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN

item.title: Inquiry Into Rape Claims Against Irish Republican Army
item.description: Among those supplying information to the authorities is Gerry Adams, the president of Sinn Fein and a member of the Irish Parliament.
item.dc:creator: By DOUGLAS DALBY

item.title: Shakespeare Folio Discovered in France
item.description: A first folio of Shakespeare’s plays — one of only 233 known examples — was discovered by chance in a public library near Calais, France.
item.dc:creator: By JENNIFER SCHUESSLER
item.media:description: The book, the 233rd known surviving first folio, was found in a public library near Calais.
